title: Your Inner Critic
description: Meet the voice inside that judges, doubts, and criticizes you. Give it a name, notice its patterns, and start building a new relationship with it — one where it doesn't run the show.

steps.title: The Voice That Never Shuts Up
steps.content: You know that voice. The one that says you're not good enough, smart enough, or far enough along. It chimes in after a mistake, before a risk, and sometimes just when you're trying to rest. Everyone has an inner critic. The problem isn't that it exists — it's that most of us think it's telling the truth.

steps.title: Defusing from Your Inner Critic
steps.content: In ACT, the inner critic is understood as a pattern of thoughts your mind produces — not a reflection of reality. Your mind evolved to spot threats, and sometimes it treats your self-worth like a survival problem. The technique of 'cognitive defusion' means creating space between you and your thoughts. Instead of 'I'm a failure,' you notice: 'I'm having the thought that I'm a failure.' That tiny shift is enormous. It doesn't make the thought go away — it just means you don't have to believe it or obey it. One powerful defusion technique is to give your inner critic a name or character. When you externalize it, it loses some of its authority. It becomes a voice you can hear without being controlled by.
steps.keyTakeaway: Your inner critic is a pattern of thoughts, not the truth — and naming it helps you stop being controlled by it.

steps.title: Name Your Inner Critic
steps.content: Let's get to know this voice. Think about the kinds of things your inner critic typically says, when it tends to show up, and what it sounds like. Then give it a name or character — something that makes it feel separate from the real you. It can be funny, serious, or anything that fits.
steps.exercisePrompt: Answer each prompt to build a profile of your inner critic.

exerciseItems.label: What does your inner critic usually say?
exerciseItems.description: Write 2-3 of its go-to phrases (e.g., 'You're going to mess this up')

exerciseItems.label: When does it get loudest?
exerciseItems.description: Situations, times of day, or triggers that bring it out

exerciseItems.label: What does it sound like?
exerciseItems.description: Harsh? Disappointed? Sarcastic? Like a specific person?

exerciseItems.label: Give it a name or character
What might it be trying to protect you from?
exerciseItems.description: Often the critic is a misguided attempt to keep you safe

steps.title: Creating Distance
steps.content: Now that you've described and named your critic, notice if it feels even slightly different. You're not trying to get rid of it — just to stop fusing with it.

reflectPrompts.prompt: Does naming your inner critic make it feel less powerful? How so?
How often does your inner critic show up in a typical day?
Can you see any way your critic has been trying to help you, even if it's not helpful?

steps.title: Catch the Critic in the Wild
steps.content: Today, when you hear that familiar critical voice, practice saying (out loud or silently): 'Oh, there's [name] again.' Don't fight it. Just notice it, name it, and gently come back to what you were doing.
steps.commitPrompt: The next time my inner critic speaks up, I'll...
commitOptions: Say 'Thanks for the input, [name]' and carry on with my day
Write down what it said and ask myself: is this fact or opinion?
Take one slow breath and remind myself: thoughts are not commands
